intro: Scutellaria galericulata var. pubens, commonly known as the hairy mouse-ear, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of western North America. It belongs to the mint family, Lamiaceae, and is characterized by its hairy, velvety foliage that gives it its common name. The plant typically grows to a height of 10–30 cm, with small, tubular flowers that range in color from blue to purple. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun to partial shade, often found in alpine and subalpine habitats. Due to its ornamental value and medicinal potential, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and studied for its pharmacological properties.
